[Ahmed Rushdi](/wiki/Ahmed_Rushdi "Ahmed Rushdi") recorded the National Anthem
of Pakistan in 1954

The **Qaumi Taranah** ([Urdu](/wiki/Urdu_language "Urdu language"): قومی
ترانہ‬‎, __Qaumī Tarānah__ pronounced [[ˈqɔː.mi
ˈt̪ə.rɑː.nɑ]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Hindi_and_Urdu "Help:IPA/Hindi and Urdu"), lit.
_“National Anthem”_), also known as _**_Pāk Sarzamīn_**_
([Urdu](/wiki/Urdu_language "Urdu language"): پاک سرزمین‬‎, pronounced [[ˈpɑːk
ˈsər.zə.miːn]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Hindi_and_Urdu "Help:IPA/Hindi and Urdu"), lit.
_“The Sacred Land”_), is the [national anthem](/wiki/National_anthem "National
anthem") of [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan"). Its music was composed by
[Ahmad G. Chagla](/wiki/Ahmed_Ghulamali_Chagla "Ahmed Ghulamali Chagla") in
1949, preceding the lyrics, which were written by [Hafeez
Jullundhri](/wiki/Hafeez_Jullundhri "Hafeez Jullundhri") in 1952. It was
officially adopted as Pakistan's national anthem in August 1954[1] and was
recorded in the same year by eleven major singers of Pakistan including [Ahmad
Rushdi](/wiki/Ahmad_Rushdi "Ahmad Rushdi"), Kaukab Jahan, Rasheeda Begum,
Najam Ara, Naseema Shaheen, Zawar Hussain, Akhtar Abbas, Ghulam Dastagir,
Anwar Zaheer and Akhtar Wasi Ali.[2]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Qaumi_Taranah&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

In early 1948, _A. R. Ghani_ , a Muslim from
[Transvaal](/wiki/Transvaal_Province "Transvaal Province"), [South
Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa"), offered two prizes of five
thousand [rupees](/wiki/Pakistani_rupee "Pakistani rupee") each for the poet
and composer of a new national anthem for the newly independent state of
Pakistan. The prizes were announced through a government press advertisement
published in June 1948. In December 1948, the [Government of
Pakistan](/wiki/Government_of_Pakistan "Government of Pakistan") established
the National Anthem Committee (NAC) with the task of coming up with the
composition and lyrics for the official national anthem of Pakistan. The NAC
was initially chaired by the Information Secretary, [Sheikh Muhammad
Ikram](/wiki/S._M._Ikram "S. M. Ikram"), and its members included several
politicians, poets and musicians, including [Abdur Rab
Nishtar](/wiki/Abdur_Rab_Nishtar "Abdur Rab Nishtar"), [Ahmad G.
Chagla](/wiki/Ahmed_Ghulamali_Chagla "Ahmed Ghulamali Chagla") and [Hafeez
Jullundhri](/wiki/Hafeez_Jullundhri "Hafeez Jullundhri").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The NAC
encountered early difficulties in finding suitable music and lyrics.

When President [Sukarno](/wiki/Sukarno "Sukarno") of
[Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia "Indonesia") became the first foreign head of
state to visit Pakistan on 30 January 1950, there was no Pakistani national
anthem to be played. In 1950, the impending state visit of the [Shah of
Iran](/wiki/Mohammad_Reza_Pahlavi "Mohammad Reza Pahlavi") added urgency to
the matter and resulted in the Government of Pakistan asking the NAC to submit
an anthem without further delay. The NAC Chairman, then Federal Minister for
Education, Fazlur Rahman, asked several poets and composers to write lyrics
but none of the submitted works were deemed suitable. The NAC also examined
several different tunes and eventually selected the one presented by Ahmed G.
Chagla and submitted it for formal approval.[3] On 21 August 1949, the
[Government of Pakistan](/wiki/Government_of_Pakistan "Government of
Pakistan") adopted Chagla’s tune for the national anthem.[4]

The anthem, without lyrics, was performed for the first time for a foreign
head of state on the state visit of the Shah of Iran to Pakistan in
[Karachi](/wiki/Karachi "Karachi") on 1 March 1950 by a [Pakistan
Navy](/wiki/Pakistan_Navy "Pakistan Navy") band.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

It was later played for [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Pakistan
"Prime Minister of Pakistan") [Liaquat Ali Khan](/wiki/Liaquat_Ali_Khan
"Liaquat Ali Khan") during his official visit to the United States on 3 May
1950. It was played before the NAC on 10 August 1950.[5] Official recognition
to the national anthem, however, was not given until August 1954.[5] The NAC
distributed records of the composed tune amongst prominent poets, who
responded by writing and submitting several hundred songs for evaluation by
the NAC. Eventually, the lyrics written by Hafeez Jullundhri were approved and
the new national anthem was broadcast publicly for the first time on Radio
Pakistan on 13 August 1954, sung by Hafeez Jullundhri himself. Official
approval was announced by the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting on 16
August 1954. The composer, Ahmed G. Chagla, died in 1953, before the new
national anthem was officially adopted. In 1955, there was a performance of
the national anthem involving 11 major singers of Pakistan, including [Ahmad
Rushdi](/wiki/Ahmad_Rushdi "Ahmad Rushdi"), Kaukab Jahan, Rasheeda Begum,
Najam Ara, Naseema Shaheen, Zawar Hussain, Akhtar Abbas, Ghulam Dastagir,
Anwar Zaheer and Akhtar Wasi Ali.[6]

## Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Qaumi_Taranah&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Music")]

The Qaumi Taranah is a melodious and harmonious rendering of a three-stanza
composition with a tune based on eastern music but arranged in such a manner
that it can be easily played by foreign bands.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The music, composed by the Pakistani musician and composer, Ahmad G. Chagla in
1949, reflects his background in both eastern and western music. Twenty-one
musical instruments[4] and thirty-eight different tones[4] are used to play
the Qaumi Taranah,[7] the duration of which is 80 seconds.[1][4][8]

## Lyrics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Qaumi_Taranah&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Lyrics")]

The [Urdu](/wiki/Urdu "Urdu") lyrics, written by the Pakistani Urdu-language
poet, Hafeez Jullundhri in 1952, have commonality with
[Persian](/wiki/Persian_language "Persian language"), making them
understandable in both languages. No verse in the three stanza lyrics is
repeated.[1] The anthem has heavy Persian poetic vocabulary,[9] and only uses
one exclusively Urdu word 'kā'.[10]

## Milestones[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Qaumi_Taranah&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Milestones")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-
new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg)|
This section **needs additional citations
for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**.
Please help [improve this
article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Qaumi_Taranah&action=edit) by
[adding citations to reliable
sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1
"Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may
be challenged and removed. _(August 2018)__([Learn how and when to remove this
template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance
template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
  * **1947** – The new state of Pakistan came into being on 14 August.
  * **1949** – Music for the Qaumi Taranah is composed by the Pakistani musical composer, [Ahmad G. Chagla](/wiki/Ahmed_Ghulamali_Chagla "Ahmed Ghulamali Chagla") (running time: 80 seconds).
  * **1950** – anthem, without lyrics, was performed for the first time for a foreign head of state on the state visit of the Shah of Iran to Pakistan in Karachi on 1 March 1950 by a Pakistan Navy band.
  * **1952** – Verses written by the Pakistani poet, [Hafeez Jullundhri](/wiki/Hafeez_Jullundhri "Hafeez Jullundhri"), are selected from amongst 723 entries.
  * **1954** – Officially adopted as the national anthem and broadcast for the first time on Radio Pakistan on 13 August
  * **1955** – Sung by 11 famous Pakistani singers including Ahmad Rushdi, Shamim Bano, Kokab Jehan, Rasheeda Begum, Najam Ara, Naseema Shaheen, Zwar Hussain, Akhtar Abbas, Ghulam Dastgir, Anwar Zaheer and Akhtar Wassi
  * **1996** – Rendered in electric guitar for the first time by Pakistani rock band [Junoon](/wiki/Junoon_\(band\) "Junoon \(band\)") in their album _[Inquilaab](/wiki/Inquilaab_\(album\) "Inquilaab \(album\)")_
  * **2009** – Rendered as an acoustic instrumental for the first time by Pakistani musician [Jehangir Aziz Hayat](/wiki/Jehangir_Aziz_Hayat "Jehangir Aziz Hayat")
  * **2011** – On 14 August, 5,857 people gathered in a stadium in [Karachi](/wiki/Karachi "Karachi") to sing the Qaumi Taranah and set a new world record for most people gathered to sing a national anthem simultaneously.[12]
  * **2012** – On 20 October, 42,813 people gathered in a stadium in [Lahore](/wiki/Lahore "Lahore") to sing the Qaumi Taranah and set a new world record for most people gathered to sing a national anthem simultaneously, which was certified by [Guinness World Records](/wiki/Guinness_World_Records "Guinness World Records").[13] The record was subsequently broken on 26 March 2014 in [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh").[14]
  * **2017** – [_Coke Studio_](/wiki/Coke_Studio_\(Pakistan\) "Coke Studio \(Pakistan\)") released a collaborative rendition of Qaumi Taranah on 4 August by the featured artistes, to celebrate the 70 years of Pakistan in the [tenth season](/wiki/Coke_Studio_Pakistan_\(season_10\) "Coke Studio Pakistan \(season 10\)").[15][16]
